sen.e: Tameyasu KATAGIRI (dates of birth and death unknown) was a samurai in the closing years of the Heian period.

sen.e: He was a son of either Kegeshige KATAGIRI (Kohachiro daibu) or Tametoo KATAGIRI (Shichiro).

sen.j: 信濃国守源為公の玄孫にあたる。
sen.e: He was a grandson of MINAMOTO no Tametomo, who was Shinano no kuni no kami (Governor of Shinano Province).

sen.j: 信濃国伊那郡片桐郷を本拠とする豪族・片桐氏の当主。
sen.e: Tameyasu was the head of the Katagiri clan, a local ruling family whose home ground was Katagiri-go, Ina-gun, Shinano Province.

sen.j: 仮名 (通称)は太郎あるいは源二。
sen.e: He was commonly called Taro or Genji.
sen.cmt: 「仮名（通称）」は「けみょう」といい「江戸時代以前に諱を呼称することを避ける為に便宜的に用いた通称のこと」と国語辞典にありますが、何と訳したらよいかわからないので、「通称」の部分を訳して commonly called としました。
sen.e: He was commonly called Taro or Genji.

sen.j: 平治の乱で父景重が源義朝方に与して敗れたことから片桐の地は以後平家領となり20年以上に渡って所領を失っていた。
sen.e: When the Heiji Disturbance occurred, his father Kageshige sided with the army of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo, but his forces were lost in the battle, which ended up changing the ownership of the Katagiri clan's fief to the Taira clan and left the Katagiri clan fiefless for over 20 years thereafter.

sen.j: 寿永3年（1184年）、鎌倉に召し出され憐憫する源頼朝によって旧領が返還された（『吾妻鏡』同年6月23日 (旧暦)条）。
sen.e: In 1184, when Tameyasu was summoned to Kamakura, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo felt sorry for him and arranged a return of his former fief to him (according to the article of June 23 (lunar calendar), 1184, of Azuma Kagami (the Mirror of the East).
